{{Infobox person | name = Bethany Brookshire | image = Bethany Brookshire.jpg | alma_mater = [[The College of William and Mary]] [[Wake Forest University School of Medicine]] | employer = [[Science News for Students]] | known_for = Science journalism }}
'''Bethany Brookshire''' is an American science journalist. She writes for [[Science News for Students]].
== Education == Brookshire completed a BA (Philosophy) and BS (Biology) at the [[College of William & Mary]] in 2004.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wm.edu/as/kecklab/studentresearch/researchwm/index.php|title=William and Mary {{!}} William & Mary|website=www.wm.edu|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.womensmediacenter.com/profile/bethany-brookshire|title=Women's Media Center|website=www.womensmediacenter.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> She earned a PhD in [[pharmacology|Physiology and Pharmacology]] at [[Wake Forest School of Medicine]] in 2010, where she worked on ritalin and the serotonin switch with Sara Jones.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/38980895_Bethany_R_Brookshire|title=Bethany R Brookshire's scientific contributions {{!}} University of Pennsylvania, PA (UP) and other places|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wakehealth.edu/PhysPharm/Faculty/Sara-R-Jones-PhD-Research-Interests.htm|title=Sara R. Jones, PhD – Research Interests|website=www.wakehealth.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> She began blogging about science in 2008, during her graduate studies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.informalscience.org/news-views/explaining-science-qa-bethany-brookshire|title=Q&A with Bethany Brookshire {{!}} InformalScience.org|website=www.informalscience.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> She wrote under the pseudonym ''SciCurious for'' [[Discover (magazine)]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/crux/2012/09/21/under-controlled-why-the-new-gmo-panic-is-more-sensational-than-sense/|title=Under Controlled: Why the New GMO Panic Is More Sensational Than Sense – The Crux|date=2012-09-21|work=The Crux|access-date=2018-03-09|language=en-US}}</ref> and [[The Guardian]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/blog/2010/sep/28/depression-serotonin-neurogenesis|title=If low serotonin levels aren't responsible for depression, what is? {{!}} Scicurious|last=Scicurious|date=2010-09-28|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/blog/2013/apr/19/beer-dopamine-brain-scans|title=Beer, dopamine and brain scans make an intoxicating mix {{!}} Scicurious|last=Scicurious|date=2013-04-19|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2011/may/18/migraine-postdrome-research|title=The postdrome: migraine's silent sister {{!}} Scicurious|last=Scicurious|date=2011-05-18|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> She worked as a postdoctoral researcher at the [[University of Pennsylvania]], where she used social media to discuss the brain and psychiatric illness.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sfn.org/Press-Room/News-Release-Archives/2012/Society-for-Neuroscience-Announces-Recipients-of-Science-Education-and-Outreach-Awards|title=Society for Neuroscience Announces Recipients of Science Education and Outreach Awards|last=|first=|date=2012-10-13|website=Society for Neuroscience|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> Here she worked with Irwin Lucki identifying the mechanisms of antidepressants in action.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Balu|first=Darrick T.|last2=Turner|first2=Jill R.|last3=Brookshire|first3=Bethany R.|last4=Hill-Smith|first4=Tiffany E.|last5=Blendy|first5=Julie A.|last6=Lucki|first6=Irwin|title=Brain monoamines and antidepressant-like responses in MRL/MpJ versus C57BL/6J mice|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0028390812005746|journal=Neuropharmacology|volume=67|pages=503–510|doi=10.1016/j.neuropharm.2012.11.027|pmc=3587166}}</ref>
== Career == In 2013, Brookshire began blogging in her own name.<ref>{{Citation|last=Bethany Brookshire|title=Hello Internet|date=2013-05-08|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_nHWS0wLEQU|accessdate=2018-03-09}}</ref> Today she writes ''Eureka!Lab'' for [[Science News for Students]], and for ''SciCurious'' for [[Science News]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scicurious.org/|title=SciCurious|website=www.scicurious.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://scicommcamp.com/speakers/bethany-brookshire/|title=BETHANY BROOKSHIRE – SciCommCamp|work=SciCommCamp|access-date=2018-03-09|language=en-US}}</ref> She presents the podcast ''[[Science for the People (podcast)|Science for the People]]'', as well as appearing on other science related shows.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tunein.com/radio/STEM-Diversity-Podcast-p1023633/|title=Listen to STEM Diversity Podcast on TuneIn|website=TuneIn|language=en-us|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/science-for-the-people/id304855471?mt=2|title=Science for the People by Rachelle Saunders & Bethany Brookshire on Apple Podcasts|website=Apple Podcasts|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> She appeared on the ''Story Collider'' in 2015, a show which tells the stories of scientists, where Brookshire discussed her quest for a mentor.<ref>{{Citation|title=Bethany Brookshire: A Perfect Mentor|url=https://soundcloud.com/the-story-collider/bethany-brookshire-a-perfect-mentor|language=en|accessdate=2018-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.podelight.com/podcast_episodes/14771/bethany-brookshire--a-perfect-mentor/details|title=The Story Collider episode: Bethany Brookshire: A Perfect Mentor|website=www.podelight.com|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> In May 2016 she published ''Science Blogging: The Essential Guide'' with Christie Wilcox and Jason Goldman.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/920017519|title=Science blogging : the essential guide|others=Wilcox, Christie, 1985–, Brookshire, Bethany,, Goldman, Jason G.,|isbn=0300197551|location=New Haven|oclc=920017519}}</ref>
She has written for ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/authors.bethany_brookshire.html|title=Bethany Brookshire|website=Slate Magazine|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> ''[[Scientific American]]'',<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/scicurious-brain/hello-internet/|title=Hello Internet!|last=Scicurious|work=Scientific American Blog Network|access-date=2018-03-09|language=en}}</ref> and The Open Notebook.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theopennotebook.com/2016/03/15/science-bloggers-on-why-they-do-it/|title=Science Bloggers on Why They Do It|date=2016-03-15|work=The Open Notebook|access-date=2018-03-09|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Awards == *2009 – Synapse Award from [[Wake Forest School of Medicine]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wakehealth.edu/SfN/Programs-and-Awards/SYNAPSE-Award.htm|title=SYNAPSE Awards for Public Outreach|website=www.wakehealth.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> *2009 – PLoS ONE Blog Pick of the Month for December *2012 – Society for Neuroscience Next Generation Award<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wakehealth.edu/uploadedFiles/User_Content/Research/Institutes_and_Centers/Society_for_Neuroscience/Neurotransmitter/Issue14_March2013_final%5B1%5D.pdf|title=The Neurotransmitter|last=|first=|date=|website=Wake Forest University School of Medicine|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> *2011 – [[3 Quarks Daily]] Science Writing Award<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.3quarksdaily.com/3quarksdaily/2011/06/the-winners-of-the-3-quarks-daily-2011-science-prize.html|title=3quarksdaily: The Winners of the 3 Quarks Daily 2011 Science Prize|website=www.3quarksdaily.com|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> *2014 – [[Sloan Foundation]] Writing Grant<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://yalebooks.yale.edu/book/9780300221077/science-blogging|title=Science Blogging {{!}} Yale University Press|website=yalebooks.yale.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> *2016 – Woods Hole Marine Biological Laboratory Logan Science Journalism Fellow<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mbl.edu/blog/mbl-awards-fellowships-to-science-and-health-journalists-to-get-their-hands-on-research-2/|title=MBL Awards Fellowships to Science and Health Journalists to "Get Their Hands On Research"|website=www.mbl.edu|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref>
== References == <references />

{{Infobox organization | name = Chemical Society Located in Taipei | pronounce = | native_name = 中國化學會 | native_name_lang = zh | named_after = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = [[Chinese Chemical Society (Beijing)|Chinese Chemical Society]] | merged = | successor = | formation = 4 August 1931 (in Nanking)
1950 (in Taiwan) | founder = | founding_location = | extinction = | merger = | type = | tax_id = | registration_id = | status = | purpose = | headquarters = [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]] | location = | coords = | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = [[Mandarin Chinese|Chinese]] | owner = | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | endowment_year = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | website = {{URL|http://chemistry.org.tw/|chemistry.org.tw}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} '''Chemical Society Located in Taipei''' ('''CSLT'''; {{zh|c=中國化學會}}; literally 'Chinese Chemical Society') is a [[Taiwan|Taiwanese]] scholarly organization dedicated to [[chemistry]].{{cite web|title=Official website of Chemical Society Located in Taipei (Chinese)|url=http://chemistry.org.tw/|accessdate=11 January 2014}} The organization traces its roots to the establishment of [[Chinese Chemical Society (Beijing)|Chinese Chemical Society]] in Nanjing in 1932 and was reestablished in Taiwan in 1950.{{cite web|title=The Chemical Society Located in Taipei|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/asia.201100659/full|publisher=Wiley Online Library|accessdate=16 April 2014|author=Chien-Hong Cheng |author2=Ling-Kang Liu |author3=Biing-jiun Uang|doi=10.1002/asia.201100659}} For political reasons, the organization's English name was changed to ''Chemical Society Located in Taipei'' although it still retains the name "Chinese Chemical Society" (中國化學會) in Chinese. == Publications == CSLT and [[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] publish a monthly periodical - Journal of the Chinese Chemical Society.{{cite web|title= Journal of the Chinese Chemical Society|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/(ISSN)2192-6549|accessdate=11 January 2014}} ==See also== * [[Education in Taiwan]] * [[Organic nomenclature in Chinese]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Portal|Taiwan}} {{Sci-stub}} [[Category:Chemistry societies]] [[Category:Science and technology in Taiwan]] [[Category:1932 establishments in China]] [[Category:1950 establishments in Taiwan]] [[Category:Organizations based in Taipei]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |image = [[File:Citizen Lab Logo.png|250px]] |formation = 2001 |type = Research Laboratory |headquarters = [[University of Toronto]] |location = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] |leader_title = Director |leader_name = [[Ronald Deibert]] |website = [https://citizenlab.ca/ citizenlab.ca] }} The '''Citizen Lab''' is an interdisciplinary laboratory based at the [[Munk School of Global Affairs]] at the [[University of Toronto]], Canada. Founded and directed by Professor [[Ronald Deibert]], the Citizen Lab studies information controls—such as [[network surveillance]] and content filtering—that impact the openness and security of the Internet and that pose threats to [[human rights]]. The Citizen Lab collaborates with research centres, organizations, and individuals around the world, and uses a "mixed methods" approach, which combines computer-generated interrogation, [[data mining]] and analysis with intensive [[field research]], qualitative [[social science]], and legal and [[policy analysis]] methods. The Citizen Lab was a founding partner of the [[OpenNet Initiative]] (2002-2013) and the [[Information Warfare Monitor]] (2002-2012) projects. The organization also developed the original design of the [[Psiphon]] censorship circumvention software, which was spun out of the Lab into a private Canadian corporation (Psiphon Inc.) in 2008. The Citizen Lab’s research outputs have made global news headlines around the world. For example, front page exclusives in ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', and ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''. In ''Tracking Ghostnet'' (2009) researchers uncovered a suspected [[cyber espionage]] network of over 1,295 infected hosts in 103 countries, a high percentage of which were high-value targets, including [[ministries of foreign affairs]], embassies, international organizations, news media, and NGOs.{{cite web|url= https://www.scribd.com/doc/13731776/Tracking-GhostNet-Investigating-a-Cyber-Espionage-Network |title=Tracking Ghostnet: Investigating a Cyber Espionage Network |date= |accessdate=March 24, 2014}} This seminal study was one of the first public reports to reveal a cyber espionage network that targeted [[civil society]] and government systems around the world. In ''Shadows in the Cloud'' (2010), researchers documented a complex ecosystem of cyber espionage that systematically compromised government, business, academic, and other computer network systems in [[India]], the offices of the [[Dalai Lama]], the [[United Nations]], and several other countries.{{cite web|url= https://www.scribd.com/doc/29435784/SHADOWS-IN-THE-CLOUD-Investigating-Cyber-Espionage-2-0 |title=Shadows in the Cloud: Investigating Cyber Espionage 2.0 |date= |accessdate=March 24, 2014}} The Citizen Lab has won a number of awards for its work. It is the first Canadian institution to win the [[MacArthur Foundation]]’s MacArthur Award for Creative and Effective Institutions (2014){{cite web | title = MacArthur Award for Creative and Effective Institutions: The Citizen Lab | url = http://www.macfound.org/maceirecipients/80/ | date = February 19, 2014 | accessdate=March 24, 2014}} and the only Canadian institution to receive a "New Digital Age" Grant (2014) from [[Google]] Executive Chairman [[Eric Schmidt]].{{cite web|url=https://citizenlab.ca/2014/03/google-executive-chairman-eric-schmidt-awards-citizen-lab-new-digital-age-grant/ |title=Google Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt Awards Citizen Lab "New Digital Age" Grant | date = March 10, 2014 | accessdate= March 24, 2014}} Past awards include the [[Canadian Library Association]]'s Advancement of Intellectual Freedom in Canada Award (2013),{{cite web | title = The Citizen Lab wins the 2013 CLA Advancement of Intellectual Freedom in Canada Award | url = http://www.cla.ca/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home&TEMPLATE=/CM/ContentDisplay.cfm&CONTENTID=13924 | date = February 6, 2013 | accessdate = March 24, 2014}} the Canadian Committee for World Press Freedom’s Press Freedom Award (2011),{{cite web | title = Citizen Lab Wins the 2011 Canadian Committee for World Press Freedom’s Press Freedom Award | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2011/05/citizen-lab-wins-2011-press-freedom-award-of-the-canadian-committee-for-world-press-freedom/ | date = May 3, 2011 | accessdate = March 24, 2014}} and the [[Canadian Journalists for Free Expression]]’s Vox Libera Award (2010).{{cite web | title = Canadian Internet Pioneer, The Citizen Lab, Wins Canadian Journalists for Free Expression Vox Libera award | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2010/11/canadian-internet-pioneer-the-citizen-lab-wins-canadian-journalists-for-free-expression-vox-libera-award/ | date = November 15, 2010 | accessdate = March 24, 2014}} In July 2014, Citizen Lab was profiled in the Ars Technica article,'' Inside Citizen Lab, the "Hacker Hothouse" protecting you from Big Brother.''{{Cite web|url = https://arstechnica.com/security/2014/07/inside-citizen-lab-the-hacker-hothouse-protecting-you-from-big-brother/|title = Inside Citizen Lab, the "Hacker Hothouse" protecting you from Big Brother|date = 30 July 2014|accessdate = |website = |publisher = Ars Technica|first = Janus |last = Kopfstein}} == Funding == The Citizen Lab is independent of government or corporate interests. Financial support for the Citizen Lab has come from the [[Ford Foundation]], the [[Open Society Institute]], the [[Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada]], the [[International Development Research Centre]] (IDRC), the Canada Centre for Global Security Studies at the University of Toronto’s Munk School of Global Affairs, the [[John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation]], the [[Donner Canadian Foundation]], the [[Open Technology Fund]], and [[The Walter and Duncan Gordon Foundation]]. The Citizen Lab has received donations of software and support from [[Palantir Technologies]], [[VirusTotal]], and Oculus Info Inc.[https://citizenlab.ca/about/ About Citizen Lab] == Research areas == === Threats against civil society === The Citizen Lab’s Targeted Threats research stream seeks to gain a better understanding of the technical and social nature of digital attacks against [[civil society]] groups and the political context that may motivate them.{{cite web | title = Comparative Analysis of Targeted Threats Against Human Rights Organizations | url = https://citizenlab.ca/hrthreats/ | accessdate = March 4, 2014}} The Citizen Lab conducts ongoing comparative analysis of a growing spectrum of online threats, including Internet filtering, denial-of-service attacks, and targeted malware. Targeted Threats reports have covered a number espionage campaigns and information operations against the [[Tibetan people|Tibetan]] community and [[Tibetan diaspora|diaspora]],{{cite web | first1 = Katie | last1 = Kleemola | first2 = Seth | last2 = Hardy | title = Surtr: Malware Family Targeting the Tibetan Community | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/08/surtr-malware-family-targeting-the-tibetan-community/ | date = August 2, 2013 | accessdate = March 24, 2014}}; {{cite web | title = Permission to Spy: An Analysis of Android Malware Targeting Tibetans | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/04/permission-to-spy-an-analysis-of-android-malware-targeting-tibetans/ | date = April 18, 2013 | accessdate = March 24, 2014}}; {{cite web | title = Recent Observations in Tibet-Related Information Operations: Advanced social engineering for the distribution of LURK malware | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2012/07/recent-observations/ | date = July 26, 2012 | accessdate = March 24, 2014}} phishing attempts made against journalists, human rights defenders, political figures, international investigators and anti-corruption advocates in Mexico,{{Cite web|url=https://citizenlab.ca/2017/08/nso-spyware-mexico-corruption/|title=Director of Mexican Anti-Corruption Group Targeted with NSO Group’s Spyware|last=John Scott-Railton, Bill Marczak, Bahr Abdul Razzak, Masashi Crete-Nishihata, and Ron Deibert|first=|date=August 30, 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} and a prominent human rights advocate who was the focus of government surveillance in the United Arab Emirates.{{Cite web|url=https://citizenlab.ca/2016/08/million-dollar-dissident-iphone-zero-day-nso-group-uae/|title=The Million Dollar Dissident: NSO Group’s iPhone Zero-Days used against a UAE Human Rights Defender|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Citizen Lab researchers and collaborators like the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] have also revealed several different malware campaigns targeting Syrian activists and opposition groups in the context of the [[Syrian Civil War]].{{cite web | last1 = Marquis-Boire | first1 = Morgan | last2 = Hardy | first2 = Seth | title = Syrian Activists Targeted with Blackshades Spy Software | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2012/06/syrian-activists-targeted-with-blackshades-spy-software/ | date = June 19, 2012 | accessdate = March 24, 2014}}; {{cite web | last1 = Scott-Railton | first1 = John | last2 = Marquis-Boire | first2 = Morgan | title = A Call to Harm: New Malware Attacks Target the Syrian Opposition | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/06/a-call-to-harm/ | date = June 21, 2013 | accessdate = March 24, 2014}}; {{cite web | last1 = Marquis-Boire | first1 = Morgan | last2 = Galperin | first2 = Eva |author2link=Eva Galperin |last3 = Scott-Railton | first3 = John | title = Quantum of Surveillance: Familiar Actors and Possible False Flags in Syrian Malware Campaigns | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/12/syrian-malware-campaigns/ | date = December 23, 2013 | accessdate = March 24, 2014}} Many of these findings were translated into [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and disseminated along with recommendations for detecting and removing malware. The Citizen Lab’s research on threats against civil society organizations has been featured on the front page of ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek|BusinessWeek]]'',{{cite web | author = Stephan Farris | title = The Hackers of Damascus | publisher = Bloomberg Businessweek | url = http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-11-15/the-hackers-of-damascus | date = November 15, 2012}} and covered in [[Al Jazeera]],{{cite web | title = New report exposes digital front of Syria's civil war | publisher = Al Jazeera | date = December 25, 2013 | url =http://america.aljazeera.com/watch/shows/the-stream/the-stream-officialblog/2013/12/25/new-report-exposesdigitalfrontofsyriascivilwar.html}} ''[[Forbes]]'',{{cite web | last = Greenberg | first = Andy | title = Evidence Mounts That Chinese Government Hackers Spread Android Malware | date = April 1, 2013 | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/04/01/evidence-mounts-that-chinese-government-hackers-spread-android-malware/}} ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'',{{cite web | last = Poulsen | first = Kevin | title = In Syria’s Civil War, Facebook Has Become a Battlefield | date = December 23, 2013 |url = https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2013/12/syria-report/}} among other international media outlets. The group reports that their work analyzing [[spyware]] used to target opposition figures in South America has triggered death threats. In September 2015 members of the group received a pop-up that said: {| class="wikitable" | We're going to analyze your brain with a bullet — and your family's, too ... You like playing the spy and going where you shouldn't, well you should know that it has a cost — your life! |} === Measuring Internet censorship === [[Image:Internet Censorship and Surveillance World Map.svg|thumb |350px |
'''[[Internet censorship and surveillance by country]] (2018)'''
{{Col begin}} {{Col-1-of-2}} {{legend|#F9D|Pervasive}} {{legend|#FDD|Substantial}} {{legend|#FFD|Selective}} {{Col-2-of-2}} {{legend|#98FB98|Little or no}} {{legend|#e0e0e0|Not classified}} {{Col end}}
Sources: [[Freedom House#Freedom on the Net|Freedom on the Net]], {{cite web |title=Freedom on the Net 2018 |url=https://freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/FOTN_2018_Final%20Booklet_11_1_2018.pdf |website=Freedom House |date=November 2018 |accessdate=1 November 2018}} [[OpenNet Initiative]],OpenNet Initiative [http://opennet.net/research/data "Summarized global Internet filtering data spreadsheet"], 8 November 2011 and [http://opennet.net/research/profiles "Country Profiles"], the OpenNet Initiative is a collaborative partnership of the Citizen Lab at the Munk School of Global Affairs, University of Toronto; the Berkman Center for Internet & Society at Harvard University; and the SecDev Group, OttawaDue to legal concerns the [[OpenNet Initiative]] does not check for filtering of [[child pornography]] and because their classifications focus on technical filtering, they do not include other types of censorship. [[Reporters Without Borders]].[http://12mars.rsf.org/2014-en/#slide2 "Internet Enemies"], ''Enemies of the Internet 2014: Entities at the heart of censorship and surveillance'', Reporters Without Borders (Paris), 11 March 2014. Retrieved 24 June 2014.[http://march12.rsf.org/i/Report_EnemiesoftheInternet_2012.pdf ''Internet Enemies''], Reporters Without Borders (Paris), 12 March 2012 ]] The OpenNet Initiative has tested for Internet filtering in 74 countries and found that 42 of them—including both authoritarian and democratic regimes—implement some level of filtering.{{cite web | title = OpenNet Initiative | url = https://opennet.net/ | accessdate = March 24, 2014}} The Citizen Lab is continuing this research area through the Internet Censorship Lab (ICLab), a project to develop new systems and methods for measuring Internet censorship. It is a collaborative effort between The Citizen Lab, Professor Phillipa Gill’s group at [[Stony Brook University]]'s Department of Computer Science, and Professor Nick Feamster’s Network Operations and Internet Security Group at [[Princeton University]].{{cite web | title = Internet Censorship Lab | url = http://www.iclab.org/ | accessdate = April 20, 2015}} === Application-level information controls === The Citizen Lab studies censorship and surveillance implemented in popular [[Application software|applications]] including social networks, instant messaging, and [[search engine]]s. Previous work includes investigations of [[censorship|censorship practices]] of search engines provided by [[Google Search|Google]], [[Bing (search engine)|Microsoft]], and [[Yahoo! Search|Yahoo!]] for the Chinese market along with the domestic Chinese search engine [[Baidu]]. In 2008, Nart Villeneuve found that [[TOM-Skype]] (the Chinese version of [[Skype]] at the time) had collected and stored millions of chat records on a publicly accessible server based in [[China]].{{cite web | title = Breaching Trust: An analysis of surveillance and security practices on China's TOM-Skype platform | year = 2008 | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/13712715/Breaching-Trust-An-analysis-of-surveillance-and-security-practices-on-Chinas-TOMSkype-platform}} In 2013, Citizen Lab researchers collaborated with Professor Jedidiah Crandall and Ph.D. student Jeffrey Knockel at the [[University of New Mexico]] to reverse engineering of TOM-Skype and [[Sina UC]], another instant messaging application used in China. The team was able to obtain the URLs and encryption keys for various versions of these two programs and downloaded the keyword blacklists daily. This work analyzed over one year and a half of data from tracking the keyword lists, examined the social and political contexts behind the content of these lists, and analyzed those times when the list had been updated, including correlations with current events.{{cite web | title = Chat program censorship and surveillance in China: Tracking TOM-Skype and Sina UC | url = http://firstmonday.org/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/4628/3727 | date = July 2013}} Current research focuses on monitoring information controls on the popular Chinese [[microblogging]] service [[Sina Weibo]],{{cite web | title = Keyword: Bo Xilai | url = https://citizenlab.ca/bo_xilai/ | accessdate = March 24, 2014}}; {{cite web | title = Visualizing Changes in Censorship: Summarizing two months of Sina Weibo keyword monitoring with two interactive charts | date = August 21, 2013 | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/08/visualizing-changes-in-censorship-summarizing-two-months-of-sina-weibo-keyword-monitoring-with-two-interactive-charts/}} Chinese online encyclopedias,{{cite web | title = Who’s the Boss? The difficulties of identifying censorship in an environment with distributed oversight: a large-scale comparison of Wikipedia China with Hudong and Baidu Baike | date = August 28, 2013 | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/08/a-large-scale-comparison-of-wikipedia-china-with-hudong-and-baidu-baike/}} and mobile messaging applications popular in Asia.{{cite web | title = Asia Chats: Analyzing Information Controls and Privacy in Asian Messaging Applications |date=November 14, 2013 | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/11/asia-chats-analyzing-information-controls-privacy-asian-messaging-applications/}} The Asia Chats project utilizes technical investigation of censorship and surveillance, assessment on the use and storage of user data, and comparison of the [[terms of service]] and [[privacy policies]] of the applications.{{cite web | title = Asia Chats: Analyzing Information Controls and Privacy in Asian Messaging Applications | date = November 14, 2013 | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/11/asia-chats-analyzing-information-controls-privacy-asian-messaging-applications/}} The first report released from this project examined regional keyword filtering mechanisms that [[LINE Corporation|LINE]] applies to its Chinese users.{{cite web | title = Asia Chats: Investigating Regionally-based Keyword Censorship in LINE | date = August 14, 2013 | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/11/asia-chats-investigating-regionally-based-keyword-censorship-line/}} Analysis of a popular cellphone app called "[[Smart Sheriff]]", by Citizen Lab and the German group [[Cure53]], asserted the app represented a security hole that betrayed the privacy of the children it was meant to protect and that of their parents. [[South Korea]]n law required all cellphones sold to those under 18 to contain software designed to protect children, and Smart Sheriff was the most popular government approved app—with 380,000 subscribers. The Citizen Lab/Cure53 report described Smart Sheriff's security holes as ''"catastrophic"''. === Commercial surveillance === The Citizen Lab conducts groundbreaking research on the global proliferation of [[targeted surveillance]] software and toolkits, including [[FinFisher]], [[Hacking Team]] and [[NSO Group]]. FinFisher is a suite of remote intrusion and surveillance software developed by [[Munich]]-based Gamma International GmbH and marketed and sold exclusively to law enforcement and intelligence agencies by the UK-based Gamma Group. In 2012, [[Morgan Marquis-Boire]] and Bill Marczak provided the first public identification of FinFisher's software. The Citizen Lab and collaborators have done extensive investigations into FinFisher, including revealing its use against Bahraini activists,{{cite web | last1 = Marquis-Boire | first1 = Morgan | last2 = Marczak | first2 = Bill | title = From Bahrain With Love: FinFisher's Spykit Exposed? | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2012/07/from-bahrain-with-love-finfishers-spy-kit-expose | date = July 25, 2012}} analyzing variants of the FinFisher suite that target mobile phone operating systems,{{cite web | last1 = Marquis-Boire | first1 = Morgan | last2 = Marczak | first2 = Bill | last3 = Gaurnieri | first3 = Claudio | title = The Smartphone Who Loved Me? FinFisher Goes Mobile | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2012/08/the-smartphone-who-loved-me-finfisher-goes-mobile/ | date = August 29, 2012}} uncovering targeted spying campaigns against political dissidents in Malaysia and Ethiopia,{{cite web | last1 = Marquis-Boire | first1 = Morgan | last2 = Marczak | first2 = Bill | last3 = Gaurnieri | first3 = Claudio | last4 = Scott-Railton | first4 = John | title = For Their Eyes Only: The Commercialization of Digital Spying | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/04/for-their-eyes-only-2/ | date = April 30, 2013}} and documenting FinFisher command and control servers in 36 countries.{{cite web | last1 = Marquis-Boire | first1 = Morgan | last2 = Marczak | first2 = Bill | last3 = Gaurnieri | first3 = Claudio | last4 = Scott-Railton | first4 = John | title = You Only Click Twice: FinFisher's Global Proliferation | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/03/you-only-click-twice-finfishers-global-proliferation-2/ | date = March 13, 2013}} Citizen Lab's FinFisher research has informed and inspired responses from civil society organizations in Pakistan,{{cite web | title = Bytes for All Petitions Pakistani Court on Presence of Surveillance Software | url = https://cyberstewards.org/2013/05/bytes-for-all-petitions-pakistani-court-on-presence-of-surveillance-software/ | date = May 16, 2013}} Mexico,{{cite web | title = Cyber Stewards Network and Local Activists Investigate FinFisher in Mexico | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/11/cyber-steward-network-local-activists-investigate-surveillance-mexico/ | date = November 8, 2013}} and the United Kingdom.{{cite web | title = OECD complaint filed by human rights groups against British surveillance company moves forward | url = https://www.privacyinternational.org/press-releases/oecd-complaint-filed-by-human-rights-groups-against-british-surveillance-company | date = June 24, 2013}} In Mexico, for example, local activists, and politicians collaborated to demand an investigation into the state’s acquisition of surveillance technologies.{{cite web | author = Renata Avila | title = Cyber Steward Network and Local Activists Investigate Surveillance in Mexico | url = https://cyberstewards.org/2013/11/cyber-steward-network-and-local-activists-investigate-surveillance-in-mexico/ | date = November 8, 2013}} In the UK, it led to a crackdown on the sale of the software over worries of misuse by repressive regimes.{{cite web | author = Jamie Doward | title = Crackdown on sale of UK spyware over fears of misuse by repressive regimes | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/sep/09/block-on-exports-surveillance-equipment | date = September 8, 2012}} Hacking Team is a [[Milan]], [[Italy]]-based company that provides intrusion and surveillance software called Remote Control System (RCS) to law enforcement and intelligence agencies. The Citizen Lab and collaborators have mapped out RCS network endpoints in 21 countries,{{cite web | last3 = Marquis-Boire | first3 = Morgan | last1 = Marczak | first1 = Bill | last2 = Gaurnieri | first2 = Claudio | last4 = Scott-Railton | first4 = John | title = Mapping Hacking Team's "Untraceable" Spyware | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2014/02/mapping-hacking-teams-untraceable-spyware/ | date = February 17, 2014}} and have revealed evidence of RCS being used to target a human rights activist in the United Arab Emirates,{{cite web | author = Morgan Marquis-Boire | title = Backdoors Are Forever? Hacking Team and the Targeting of Dissent | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2012/10/backdoors-are-forever-hacking-team-and-the-targeting-of-dissent/ | date = October 10, 2012}}; {{cite web | author = Vernon Silver | title = Spyware Leaves Trail to Beaten Activist through Microsoft Flaw | date = October 10, 2012 | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-10-10/spyware-leaves-trail-to-beaten-activist-through-microsoft-flaw.html}} a Moroccan citizen journalist organization,{{cite web | author = Morgan Marquis-Boire | title = Backdoors Are Forever? Hacking Team and the Targeting of Dissent | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2012/10/backdoors-are-forever-hacking-team-and-the-targeting-of-dissent/ | date = October 10, 2012}}; {{cite web | author = Nicole Perlroth | title = Ahead of Spyware Conference More Evidence of Abuse | url = http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/10/10/ahead-of-spyware-conference-more-evidence-of-abuse/ | date = October 10, 2012}} and an independent news agency run by members of the Ethiopian diaspora.{{cite web | last3 = Marquis-Boire | first3 = Morgan | last1 = Marczak | first1 = Bill | last2 = Gaurnieri | first2 = Claudio | last4 = Scott-Railton | first4 = John | title = Hacking Team and the Targeting of Ethiopian Journalists | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2014/02/hacking-team-targeting-ethiopian-journalists/ | date = February 12, 2014}} Following the publication of Hacking Team and the Targeting of Ethiopian Journalists, the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]]{{cite web | title = American Sues Ethiopian Government for Spyware Infection | url = https://www.eff.org/press/releases/american-sues-ethiopian-government-spyware-infection | publisher = [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] | date = February 18, 2014}} and Privacy International{{cite web | title = Privacy International seeking investigation into computer spying on refugee in UK | url = https://www.privacyinternational.org/press-releases/privacy-international-seeking-investigation-into-computer-spying-on-refugee-in-uk | publisher = Privacy International | date = February 17, 2014}} both took legal action related to allegations that the Ethiopian government had compromised the computers of Ethiopian expatriates in the United States and UK. In 2017, the group released several reports that showcased phishing attempts in Mexico that used NSO Group technology, an Israeli-based "cyber warfare firm". The products were used in multiple attempts to gain control of mobile devices of Mexican government officials, journalists, lawyers, human rights advocates and anti-corruption workers.{{Cite web|url=https://citizenlab.ca/tag/reckless/|title=Collection of reports on phishing attempts using NSO technology in the United Arab Emirates and Mexico|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The operations used SMS messages as bait in an attempt to trick targets into clicking on links to the NSO Group’s exploit infrastructure. Clicking on the links would lead to the remote infection of a target’s phone. In one case, the son of one of the journalists—a minor at the time—was also targeted. NSO, who purports to only sell products to governments, also came under the group’s focus when prominent UAE human rights defender Ahmed Mansoor’s mobile phone was targeted. The report on these attempts prompted Apple to release a security update to their iOS 9.3.5. The Citizen Lab’s research on surveillance software has been featured on the front pages of ''[[The Washington Post]]''{{cite web | author = Craig Timberg | title = Foreign regimes use spyware against journalists, even in U.S. | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/foreign-regimes-use-spyware-against-journalists-even-in-us/2014/02/12/9501a20e-9043-11e3-84e1-27626c5ef5fb_story.html | publisher = The Washington Post | date = February 12, 2014}} and ''[[The New York Times]]''{{cite web | author = Nicole Perlroth | title = Software Meant to Fight Crime is Used to Spy on Dissidents | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/31/technology/finspy-software-is-tracking-political-dissidents.html?_r=0 | publisher = The New York Times | date = August 30, 2012}} and covered extensively in news media around the world, including the BBC,{{cite web | title = Mozilla accuses Finfisher makers of 'hiding' under name | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-22372027 | publisher = BBC | date = May 1, 2013}} Bloomberg,{{cite web | author = Vernon Silver | title = Gamma FinSpy Surveillance Servers in 25 Countries | publisher = Bloomberg Businessweek | date = March 13, 2013 | url = http://www.businessweek.com/news/2013-03-13/gamma-finspy-surveillance-servers-in-25-countries}} CBC, Slate,{{cite web | author = Ryan Gallagher | title = Report: Global Network of Government Spyware Detected in U.S., Authoritarian Countries | publisher = Slate | date = March 13, 2013 | url = http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2013/03/13/finspy_from_gamma_group_detected_around_the_world_says_citizen_lab_report.html}} and Salon.{{cite web | author = Natasha Lennard | title = Surveillance software used to spy on activists around the world | publisher = Salon | date = March 13, 2013 | url = http://www.salon.com/2013/03/13/surveillance_software_used_to_spy_on_activists_around_the_world/}} The Citizen Lab’s research on commercial surveillance technologies has resulted in legal and policy impacts. In December 2013, the [[Wassenaar Arrangement]] was amended to include two new categories of surveillance systems on its Dual Use control list—"intrusion software" and "IP Network surveillance systems".{{cite web | title = International agreement reached controlling export of mass and intrusive surveillance technology | url = https://www.privacyinternational.org/blog/international-agreement-reached-controlling-export-of-mass-and-intrusive-surveillance | publisher = Privacy International | date = December 9, 2013}} The Wassenaar Arrangement seeks to limit the export of conventional arms and dual-use technologies by calling on signatories to exchange information and provide notification on export activities of goods and munitions included in its control lists. The amendments in December 2013 were the product of intense lobbying by civil society organizations and politicians in Europe, whose efforts were informed by Citizen Lab’s research on intrusion software like FinFisher and surveillance systems developed and marketed by [[Blue Coat Systems]].{{cite web | title = Shedding Light on the Surveillance Industry: The importance of evidence-based, impartial research | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/12/shedding-light-on-the-surveillance-industry/ | date = December 20, 2013}} === Commercial filtering === The Citizen Lab studies the commercial market for censorship and surveillance technologies, which consists of a range of products that are capable of content filtering as well as passive surveillance. The Citizen Lab has been developing and refining methods for performing Internet-wide scans to measure Internet filtering and detect externally visible installations of URL filtering products. The goal of this work is to develop simple, repeatable methodologies for identifying instances of internet filtering and installations of devices used to conduct censorship and surveillance. The Citizen Lab has conducted research into companies such as Blue Coat Systems, Netsweeper, and [[Secure Computing|SmartFilter]]. Major reports include "Some Devices Wander by Mistake: Planet Blue Coat Redux" (2013),{{cite web | first1 = Morgan | last1 = Marquis-Boire | first2 = Collin | last2 = Anderson | first3 = Jakub | last3 = Dalek | first4 = Sarah | last4 = McKune | first5 = John | last5 = Scott-Railton | title = Some Devices Wander By Mistake: Planet Blue Coat Redux | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/07/planet-blue-coat-redux/ | date = July 9, 2013}} "O Pakistan, We Stand on Guard for Thee: An Analysis of Canada-based Netsweeper’s Role in Pakistan’s Censorship Regime" (2013),{{cite web|url=https://citizenlab.ca/2013/06/o-pakistan/|title=O Pakistan, We Stand on Guard for Thee: An Analysis of Canada-based Netsweeper’s Role in Pakistan’s Censorship Regime|last=Jakub Dalek, Adam Senft, Masashi Crete-Nishihata, and Ron Deibert|first=|date=June 20, 2013|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} and Planet Blue Coat: Mapping Global Censorship and Surveillance Tools (2013).{{cite web | first1 = Morgan | last1 = Marquis-Boire | first2 = Jakub | last2 = Dalek | first3 = Sarah | last3 = McKune | title = Planet Blue Coat: Mapping Global Censorship and Surveillance Tools | url = https://citizenlab.ca/2013/01/planet-blue-coat-mapping-global-censorship-and-surveillance-tools/ | date = January 15, 2013}} This research has been covered in news media around the world, including the front page of ''[[The Washington Post]]'',{{cite web | author = Ellen Nakashima | title = Report: Web monitoring devices made by U.S. firm Blue Coat detected in Iran, Sudan | publisher = The Washington Post | date = July 8, 2013 | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/report-web-monitoring-devices-made-by-us-firm-blue-coat-detected-in-iran-sudan/2013/07/08/09877ad6-e7cf-11e2-a301-ea5a8116d211_story.html}} ''[[The New York Times]]'',{{cite web | author = John Markoff | title = Rights Group Reports on Abuses of Surveillance and Censorship Technology | publisher = The New York Times | date = January 16, 2013 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/16/business/rights-group-reports-on-abuses-of-surveillance-and-censorship-technology.html?_r=1&adxnnl=1&adxnnlx=1395760033-9bCGrQstBSdqWAvn/hS60Q}} ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'',{{cite web | author = Omar El Akkad | title = Canadian technology tied to online censorship in Pakistan | publisher = The Globe and Mail | date = June 21, 2013 | url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/canadian-technology-tied-to-online-censorship-in-pakistan/article12758332/}} and the Jakarta Post.{{cite web | author = Irene Poetranto | title = Time for Greater Transparency | publisher = [[The Jakarta Post]] | date = December 14, 2013 | url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/12/14/time-greater-transparency-surveillance.html}} Following the 2011 publication of "Behind Blue Coat: Investigations of Commercial Filtering in Syria and Burma", Blue Coat Systems officially announced that it would no longer provide "support, updates. or other services" to software in Syria.{{cite web|url=https://citizenlab.ca/2011/11/behind-blue-coat/|title=Behind Blue Coat: Investigations of commercial filtering in Syria and Burma|last=Jakub Dalek and Adam Senft|first=|date=November 9, 2011|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} In December 2011, the [[U.S. Department of Commerce]]'s [[Bureau of Industry and Security]] reacted to the Blue Coat evidence and imposed a $2.8 million fine on the Emirati company responsible for purchasing filtering products from Blue Coat and exporting them to Syria without a license. Citizen Lab's Netsweeper research has been cited by [[Pakistan]]i civil society organizations Bytes for All and [[Bolo Bhi]] in public interest litigation against the Pakistani government and in formal complaints to the High Commission (Embassy) of Canada to Pakistan.{{cite web | title = Letter to High Commissioner Of Canada : Call for Transparency, Accountability & Action Following Reports On Netsweeper’s Presence in Pakistan | publisher = Bolo Bhi | date = July 23, 2013 | url = http://bolobhi.org/canada-government-letter-netsweeper-pakistan/}} == Policy engagement == The Citizen Lab is an active participant in various global discussions on Internet governance, such as the [[Internet Governance Forum]], [[ICANN]], and the United Nations Government Group of Experts on Information and Telecommunications. Since 2010, the Citizen Lab has helped organize the annual Cyber Dialogue conference, hosted by the Munk School of Global Affairs’ Canada Centre, which convenes over 100 individuals from countries around the world who work in government, civil society, academia, and private enterprise in an effort to better understand the most pressing issues in cyberspace.{{cite web | title = Cyber Dialogue | url = http://www.cyberdialogue.ca/ | accessdate = March 25, 2014}} The Cyber Dialogue has a participatory format that engages all attendees in a moderated dialogue on Internet security, governance, and human rights. Other conferences around the world, including a high-level meeting by the Hague-based [[Scientific Council for Government Policy]] and the Swedish government’s [[Stockholm Internet Forum]], have taken up themes inspired by discussions at the Cyber Dialogue. == Field building == The Citizen Lab contributes to [[capacity building|field building]] by supporting networks of researchers, advocates, and practitioners around the world, particularly from the [[North–South divide|Global South]]. The Citizen Lab has developed regional networks of activists and researchers working on information controls and human rights for the past ten years. These networks are in Asia (OpenNet Asia), the Commonwealth of Independent States (OpenNet Eurasia), and the Middle East and North Africa.{{cite web | title = ONI Asia | url = http://www.oni-asia.net/ | accessdate = March 25, 2014}} With the support of the [[International Development Research Centre]] (IDRC), the Citizen Lab launched the Cyber Stewards Network in 2012, which consists of South-based researchers, advocates, and practitioners who analyze and impact [[cybersecurity]] policies and practices at the local, regional, and international level. The project consists of 24 partners from across Asia, sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America, and the Middle East and North Africa{{cite web | title = Cyber Stewards Network | url = http://cyberstewards.org/ | accessdate = March 25, 2014}} including [[7iber]], [[OpenNet (organization)|OpenNet]], and the [[Centre for Internet and Society (India)|Centre for Internet and Society]]. Citizen Lab staff also work with local partners to educate and train at-risk communities. For example, in 2013 it collaborated with the [[Tibet Action Institute]] to hold public awareness events in [[Dharamshala]], [[India]], for the [[Tibetan diaspora|exiled Tibetan]] community on cyber espionage campaigns.{{cite web | title = Tibet Action Institute: Safe Travels Online Tech Meet | date = June 12, 2013 | url = https://cyberstewards.org/2013/06/public-awareness-program-on-internet-security-and-a-talk-on-targeted-threats-against-the-tibetan-community/}} In the winter of 2013, the Citizen Lab conducted a digital security training session for Russian investigative journalists at the Sakharov Center in [[Moscow]].{{cite web | title = Дискуссия "Современные угрозы информационной безопасности для НКО, активистов и журналистов" | publisher = Sakharov Center | date = December 17, 2013 | url = http://www.sakharov-center.ru/discussions/?id=2402}} == In the Media == The Citizen Lab's work is often cited in media stories relating to digital security, privacy controls, government policy, human rights, and technology. Since 2006, they have been featured on 22 front-page stories at publications including ''The New York Times'', Washington Post, Globe and Mail and International Herald Tribune. == Citizen Lab Summer Institute == Since 2013, Citizen Lab has hosted the Summer Institute on Monitoring Internet Openness and Rights as an annual research workshop at the Munk School of Global Affairs, University of Toronto. It brings together researchers and practitioners from academia, civil society, and the private sector who are working on Internet openness, security, and rights. Collaborations formed at CLSI workshops have led to publication of high impact reports on Internet filtering in Zambia,{{Cite web|url=https://ooni.torproject.org/post/zambia-election-monitoring/|title=Zambia: Internet censorship during the 2016 general elections?|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} a security audit of child monitoring apps in South Korea,{{Cite web|url=https://citizenlab.ca/2015/09/digital-risks-south-korea-smart-sheriff/|title=Are the Kids Alright?|last=Collin Anderson, Masashi Crete-Nishihata, Chris Dehghanpoor, Ron Deibert, Sarah McKune, Davi Ottenheimer, and John Scott-Railton|first=|date=September 20, 2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://citizenlab.ca/2017/09/safer-without-korean-child-monitoring-filtering-apps/|title=Safer Without: Korean Child Monitoring and Filtering Apps|last=Fabian Faessler, Geoffrey Alexander, Masashi Crete-Nishihata, Andrew Hilts, and Kelly Kim|first=|date=September 11, 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} and an analysis of the "Great Cannon",{{Cite web|url=https://citizenlab.ca/2015/04/chinas-great-cannon/|title=China's Great Cannon|last=Bill Marczak, Nicholas Weaver, Jakub Dalek, Roya Ensafi, David Fifield, Sarah McKune, Arn Rey, John Scott-Railton, Ron Deibert, and Vern Paxson|first=|date=April 10, 2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} an attack tool in China used for large scale distributed-denial of service attacks against Github and GreatFire.org. ==References== {{reflist|2|refs= {{cite news | url = https://www.thestar.com/business/2015/12/09/south-american-hackers-attacking-journalists-opposition-u-of-t-team-finds.html | title = South American hackers attacking journalists, opposition, U of T team finds | publisher = [[Toronto Star]] | author = Frank Bajak | date = 2015-12-15 | accessdate = 2016-01-09 | quote = Researchers said Packrat sent a top Argentine journalist, Jorge Lanata, the identical virus that Nisman received a month before his death. }} {{cite news | url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/citizen-lab-packrat-1.3357099 | title = Packrat malware targets dissidents, journalists in South America, Citizen Lab finds: Probe started after Packrat targeted Argentine special prosecutor found dead of gunshot wound | publisher = [[CBC News]] | author = | date = 2015-12-09 | accessdate = 2016-01-09 | quote = }} {{cite news | url = http://www.csmonitor.com/Technology/2015/1102/South-Korea-pulls-plug-on-child-surveillance-app-after-security-concerns | title = South Korea pulls plug on child surveillance app after security concerns: Government officials pulled Smart Sheriff, an app that lets parents track how their children use social media, from the Google Play store over the weekend | publisher = [[Christian Science Monitor]] | author = Max Lewontin | date = 2015-11-02 | accessdate = 2016-01-09 | quote = But researchers from Citizens Lab, a research group based at the University of Toronto, and Cure53, a German software company, released two reports in September finding that Smart Sheriff had a variety of security issues that it made it vulnerable to hackers and put children and parents’ personal information at risk. }} {{cite news | url = https://www.thestar.com/business/2015/11/02/south-korea-shuts-down-child-surveillance-app-over-security-concerns.html | title = South Korea shuts down child surveillance app over security concerns: The removal of the state-approved Smart Sheriff is a blow to South Korea's effort to keep closer tabs on the online lives of youth. | publisher = [[Toronto Star]] | author = Raphael Satter, Youkyung Lee | location = [[Seoul]] | date = 2015-11-02 | accessdate = 2016-01-09 | quote = Pulling the plug on Smart Sheriff was "long overdue," said independent researcher Collin Anderson, who worked with Internet watchdog group Citizen Lab and German software auditing firm Cure53 to comb through the app’s code. }} {{cite news | url = http://www.brownpoliticalreview.org/2012/10/interview-citizens-lab-director-ronald-deibert/ | title = BPR Interview: Citizens Lab Director Ronald Deibert | publisher = [[Brown Political Review]] | author = | date = 2012-10-21 | accessdate = 2016-01-09 | quote = BPR interviewed Ronald Deibert, director of Citizens Lab at the Munk School of Global Affairs, University of Toronto, an interdisciplinary research organization focusing at the intersection of internet, global security and human rights. They have worked for the office of the Dalai Lama. }} }} ==External links== * {{Official website|https://citizenlab.ca }} * [http://cyberstewards.org Cyber Stewards Network] * [http://psiphon.ca Psiphon] * [http://opennet.net/ OpenNet Initiative] * [http://www.infowar-monitor.net/ Information Warfare Monitor] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081029085950/http://deibert.citizenlab.org/Circ_guide.pdf Everyone's Guide to By-Passing Internet Censorship for Citizens Worldwide] * [http://www.tracking-ghost.net/ Tracking GhostNet: Investigating a cyber espionage network]{{Dead link|date=September 2018}} [[Category:University of Toronto]] [[Category:Laboratories]] [[Category:Computer surveillance]] [[Category:Internet-related organizations]] [[Category:2001 establishments in Ontario]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2001]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Constantijn Huygens Jr. | image = Constantijn Huygens, Jr portrait.png | image_size = 250px | caption = Constantijn Huygens Jr., self portrait (1685) | birth_date = 10 March 1628 | birth_place = [[The Hague]], [[Dutch Republic]] | death_date = October 1697 | death_place = The Hague | residence = [[Netherlands]], [[France]], [[England]] | nationality = [[Netherlands|Dutch]] | field = [[Astronomy]]
[[Optics]] | work_institution = | alma_mater = [[Leiden University|University of Leiden]] | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | known_for = [[Aerial telescope]], diaries | influences = | influenced = | prizes = | spouse = Susanna Rijckaert | children = 2 | footnotes = }} '''Constantijn Huygens Jr., Lord of Zuilichem''' (10 March 1628 – October 1697) was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] statesman and poet, mostly known for his work on scientific instruments (sometimes in conjunction with his younger brother [[Christiaan Huygens]]). But, he was also a chronicler of his times, revealing the importance of [[gossip]].{{cite book |title=Family, Culture and Society in the Diary of Constantijn Huygens Jr. |first=Rudolf M. |last= Dekker |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iAckR8sfwfAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Constantijn+Huygens+jr&hl=en&sa=X&ei=OA4fUsaHPI6QhQfW54CwDg&sqi=2&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Constantijn%20Huygens%20jr&f=false}} Le "Journaal" de C. Huygens, le jeune : extraits réunis et commentés / par Jean Gessler. La Haye : Nĳhoff. 1933 http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/009018674 Besides he was an amateur draughtsman of [[landscape art|landscapes]]. ==Biography== Constantijn was the eldest son of Sir [[Constantijn Huygens]], a poet and statesman and [[Suzanna van Baerle]]. He was taught at home by his father and private tutors. In 1637 his mother died.{{cite web|url=http://www.essentialvermeer.com/history/huygens.html |title=Essential Vermeer |publisher=Essential Vermeer |date= |accessdate=2014-03-08}} Around 1640 the family was depicted by [[Adriaen Hanneman]]. Along with his brother Christiaan, he began his studies at [[Leiden university]] in 1645 studying Law and also taking some liberal Arts courses.{{cite web |url=http://www.physics.ubc.ca/~berciu/PHILIP/TEACHING/PHYS340/NOTES/FILES/huyghens.pdf |title=.physics.ubc.ca - LIFE of CHRISTIAAN HUYGHENS: Brief Notes, page 1 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2014-03-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219163610/http://www.physics.ubc.ca/~berciu/PHILIP/TEACHING/PHYS340/NOTES/FILES/huyghens.pdf |archivedate=2012-02-19 |df= }} These studies included the works of Classical authors on history, philosophy, and science, including mathematics from [[Frans van Schooten]]. In 1649–1650 he accompanied [[Adriaen Pauw]] to England {{cite web|url=https://ilibrariana.wordpress.com/2012/02/29/adriaan-pauw-jr-1622-1697/ |title=Adriaan Pauw jr. (1622-1697) | Librariana |publisher=Ilibrariana.wordpress.com |date=2012-02-29 |accessdate=2014-03-08}} and toured through Belgium, France, Switzerland and Italy. In 1655 Constantijn moved to Paris. He joined the circle around [[Honoré Fabri]]. In the Hague he also was visiting the salon, organized by the wife of [[François Caron]]. In 1668 he married Susanna Rijckaert (1642–1712), a rich woman from Amsterdam.{{cite web|url=http://burckhardt.ic.uva.nl/ecartico/persons/12743 |title=Susanna Ryckaert |publisher=Burckhardt.ic.uva.nl |date= |accessdate=2014-03-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/_nie012199401_01/_nie012199401_01_0030.php |title=DBNL |publisher=DBNL |date= |accessdate=2014-03-08}} In April 1676, during his stay in [[Zemst]] he was visited by [[David Teniers the Younger]]. In 1680 Constantijn Jr. visited [[Celle]] and moved out of his father's house. It is not sure if it had to do with [[Abraham de Wicquefort]] or [[Sophia Dorothea of Celle]]. To stop the gossip his father wrote a poem ''Cluijs-werck''. When [[William III of England]] became [[stadtholder]] in 1672 Constantijn Jr. had been appointed as his secretary.Family, Culture and Society in the Diary of Constantijn Huygens Jr, Secretary to Stadholder-King William of Orange by Rudolf Dekker [http://www.brill.com/family-culture-and-society-diary-constantijn-huygens-jr-secretary-stadholder-king-william-orange] Constantijn participated in the campaigns against the French, in the [[Glorious Revolution]], but did not attend the crowning. He described the [[Battle of the Boyne]]. During the [[Nine Years' War]], Constantijn left for the [[Spanish Netherlands|Southern Netherlands]] each spring, returning to London each autumn.{{cite web|url=http://www.dcs.warwick.ac.uk/bshm/zingaz/LondonPeopleH.html |title=British Society for the History of Mathematics |publisher=Dcs.warwick.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-03-08}} Constantijn became friends with or wrote about the [[Groom of the Stole]] [[William Bentinck, 1st Earl of Portland|William Bentinck]], [[Arnold van Keppel, 1st Earl of Albemarle]], [[William Nassau de Zuylestein, 1st Earl of Rochford|William Nassau de Zuylestein]], [[Everhard van Weede Dijkvelt]], [[Coenraad van Beuningen]] and [[Adrian Beverland]]. When [[William Blathwayt]] surpassed him as secretary, Constantijn was frustrated and in 1695 he received permission to return to the [[Dutch Republic]]. Hugens was buried on 2 November 1697. The couple had one son, who died in 1704; Constantijn had one daughter from an earlier affair. ==Telescopes and optics== [[File:Aerialtelescope.jpg|thumb|Tubeless [[aerial telescope]] from Christiaan and Constantijn Huygens]] Around 1650 when Christiaan Huygens became interested in microscopes and telescopes, Constantijn helped him with the construction of the lenses. In 1655 Christiaan discovered [[Titan (moon)|Titan]], a moon orbiting [[Saturn]].[http://www.museumboerhaave.nl/collectie/e_voorwerpen/telescoopHuygens.html Museumboerhaave.nl] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070709154419/http://www.museumboerhaave.nl/collectie/e_voorwerpen/telescoopHuygens.html |date=July 9, 2007 }} Between 1683 and 1687 Constantijn and his brother continued to make larger and longer [[focal length]] telescope [[Objective (optics)|objectives]] culminating in the very large tubeless [[aerial telescope]]s. He presented a 7.5 inch (190mm) diameter 123 ft (37.5 m) focal length aerial telescope objective to the [[Royal Society]] in 1690{{cite web|url=http://www.stjarnhimlen.se/bigtel/LargestTelescope.html |title=Paul Schlyter, ''Largest optical telescopes of the world'' |publisher=Stjarnhimlen.se |date= |accessdate=2014-03-08}} that still bears his signature.In 1725 the [[Royal Society]] also acquired two very long focal length aerial telescope objectives, both made by Constantijn. ==Diary== From 1673 to 1696, Huygens kept a private diary (now at the [[National Library of the Netherlands|Koninklijke Bibliotheek]]). Between 1649 and 1697 Huygens filled 1,599 pages.{{cite web|author=Dekker, R.M. (Rudolf) |url=http://repub.eur.nl/res/pub/17079/ |title=RePub, Erasmus University Repository: Sexuality, Elites, and Court Life in the Late Seventeenth Century: The Diaries of Constantijn Huygens Jr |publisher=Repub.eur.nl |date=1999-11-01 |accessdate=2014-03-08}}His journals, covering period 1673, 1675-1678, 1688-1696, were published in six volumes by the Historisch Genootschap te Utrecht, 1876-1915. In this diary he recorded all aspects of early-modern [[Noble court|court life]] in Holland and England.{{cite web|url=http://www.onderzoekinformatie.nl/nl/oi/biza/d42100o/OND1334266/ |title=Project: Court culture, time consciousness and the development of autobiographical writing in the seventeenth century. An analysis of the diary of Constantijn Huygens Jr. (1628-1697) in a social and cultural context |publisher=Onderzoekinformatie.nl |date= |accessdate=2014-03-08}} The book includes chapters on such subjects as the changing perception of time, book collecting, Huygens's role as connoisseur of art, belief in magic and witchcraft, and gossip and sexuality at the court of William and Mary. It provides an insight on the history of [[human sexuality]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=enUIIGNZiY4C&pg=PA133 |first1=Pamela H.|last1=Smith|year=2008|isbn=978-0-226-76329-3 |first2=Benjamin|last2=Schmidt|title=Making Knowledge in Early Modern Europe: Practices, Objects, and Texts, 1400 - 1800|page=133}} Huygens is comparable to his English contemporary, [[Samuel Pepys]], but with an important difference: whereas Pepys mainly describes his own sexual habits, Huygens almost exclusively describes those of others. ==Drawings and paintings== [[File:Constantijn Huygens, Jr - Kasteel Zuilichem (1657).jpg|thumb|left|A pencil drawing of Castle Zuilichem attributed to Huygens with inscriptions: "'t huijs te Zuylichem" and "August 1657". The castle was renovated by Constantijn Huygens Sr. in 1630.]] Like his ancestor [[Joris Hoefnagel]] Constantijn practised his skill in drawing. With the death of his father in 1687, he inherited the [[Heerlijkheid]] and the castle of [[Zuilichem]] (nearby [[Zaltbommel]]), by which he became known as Lord of Zuilichem (in Dutch: Heer van Zuilichem).http://www.nationalgallery.ie/en/Conservation/Featured_Projects/Battle_Of_Boyne/Project_Blog/Blog13_30Sept.aspx The Lord of Zuilichem] - website of the National Gallery of Ireland[http://www.essentialvermeer.com/history/huygens.html#.WJfHs1XhDIU Constantijn Huygens: Lord of Zuilichem] - website of Essential Vermeer Huygens Jr. made some drawings and paintings, depicting this castle in the period between 1650 till 1660.HUYGENS Jr. - REDAKTIE, MET HUYGENS OP REIS Tekeningen en dagboeknotities van Constantijn Huygens jr. (1628-1697), secretaris van stadhouder-koning Willem III. Dutch text. Ant., 1983. They can be seen at the museum [[Maarten van Rossum]] at Zaltbommel. Constantijn was an art connoisseur and advised setting up the gallery in [[Kensington Palace]]. He is connected to the [[Codex Windsor]] and the [[Codex Huygens]].Henry Schuman (Ed.) Leonardo on the human body, p. 34. Courier Dover Publications, Mineola N.Y. 1983, {{ISBN|978-0-486-24483-9}}Erwin Panofsky, The Codex Huygens and Leonardo da Vinci's art theory00, the Pierpont Morgan Library codex M.A. 1139, London: The Warburg Institute, 1940. According to Huygens [[Romeyn de Hooghe]] illustrated '' La puttana errante'', an erotic book by [[Pietro Aretino]].{{cite web|url=http://repub.eur.nl/res/pub/17079/Rudolf%20Dekker%20and%20Judy%20Marcure%20-%20Sexuality%2C%20Elites%2C%20and%20Court%20Life%20in%20the%20La.pdf |title=Rudolf Dekker and Judy Marcure - Sexuality, Elites, and Court Life in the Late Seventeenth Century: The Diaries of Constantijn Huygens Jr. - Eighteenth-Century Life 23:3 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2014-03-08}} {{Clear}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Constantijn Huygens Jr.}} * {{nl}} [http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/molh003nieu01_01/molh003nieu01_01_1863.php DBNL] * [http://vimeo.com/68603981 Rudolf M. Dekker on Constantijn Huygens Jr] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Huygens, Constantijn Jr.}} [[Category:1628 births]] [[Category:1697 deaths]] [[Category:17th-century astronomers]] [[Category:Dutch astronomers]] [[Category:Leiden University alumni]] [[Category:Writers from The Hague]] [[Category:Scientific instrument makers]] [[Category:Dutch art collectors]] [[Category:Christiaan Huygens]] [[Category:Huygens family|Constantijn Jr.]]

revision.text:
The '''Council for Science and Technology''' ('''CST''') is an advisory [[non-departmental public body]] of the [[United Kingdom]] [[Her Majesty's Government|government]]. Its role is to give advice on issues that cut across government departments to the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]], the [[First Minister of Scotland]] and the [[First Minister for Wales]]. It was established in 1993 and relaunched in 2003. It is based in [[London]].
The Council has 17 independent members and two co-chairs. Professor Dame [[Nancy Rothwell]] chairs meetings where advice is being developed. Sir [[Mark Walport]], the [[Chief Scientific Adviser to the UK Government|Chief Scientific Adviser]] and head of the [[Government Office for Science]], chairs meetings reporting its advice to government.
The advisory functions of the CST had previously been performed by the Advisory Council for Applied Research and Development (ACARD), from 1976 to 1987, and the Advisory Council on Science and Technology (ACOST) from 1987 to 1993.
==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.bseinquiry.gov.uk/report/volume2/chaptee2.htm#825569 "How research was commissioned and funded", The BSE Inquiry Report, vol.2 pt.1 sect.6]
==External links== * [http://www.cst.gov.uk/ CST website]
{{Science and technology in the United Kingdom}}
[[Category:2003 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Department for Business, Innovation and Skills]] [[Category:Non-departmental public bodies of the United Kingdom government]] [[Category:Science advocacy organizations]] [[Category:Scientific organisations based in the United Kingdom]]
{{UK-gov-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''DARPA FORESTER''' is a technology development program sponsored jointly by the [[Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency]] (DARPA) and the [[U.S. Army]] intended to produce an advanced airborne UHF radar system that can track personnel and vehicles on the ground when they are hidden by foliage. ''FORESTER'' is an acronym for '''''FO''PEN Reconnaissance, Surveillance, Tracking and Engagement Radar''' (''FOPEN'' itself is an acronym for FOliage PENetration).<ref name=darpafact>[http://www.darpa.mil/ipto/programs/forester/forester.asp DARPA Fact Sheet]</ref>
==Description== The FORESTER is a [[Moving target indication|GMTI radar]] system with a resolution of 6 meters<ref name=signal1>[http://www.afcea.org/signal/articles/templates/Signal_Article_Template.asp?articleid=1323&zoneid=209 Robinson, Clarence Jr, "Radar Counters Camouflage", ''Signal Online'' Armed Forces Communications and Electronics Association]</ref> that is mounted inside a {{convert|21.5|ft|m|adj=on}} long pod and designed to be carried under an [[Boeing A160 Hummingbird|A160 Hummingbird]] helicopter [[unmanned aerial vehicle]] (UAV).<ref name=darpafact2>[http://www.darpa.mil/ipto/programs/forester/forester_approach.asp DAPRA FORESTER fact sheet, page 2]</ref> The system is able to detect vehicles and walking soldiers underneath tree cover from a distance of {{convert|30|mi|km}}, giving battle planners the ability to detect potential ambushes. The pod is designed to swivel from its stowed in-line position 90 degrees to its deployed position. From a helicopter UAV hovering at {{convert|20000|ft|m}}, FORESTER can cover a {{convert|155|sqmi|km2|adj=on}} area.<ref name=avweek080331>[http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/aw033108p1.xml Norris, Guy, "Boeing Rotary UAV Aims To Set Records", ''Aviation Week & Space Technology'', March 30, 2008, accessed August 29, 2008]</ref>
According to FORESTER program manager Lyndall Beamer, "Employing the sensor system on the DARPA/U.S. Army [[Boeing A160 Hummingbird|A160 Hummingbird]] unmanned aerial vehicle [UAV] helicopter or other suitable platform will provide a robust, wide-area, all-weather, standoff capability."<ref name=signal1/>
Cost is anticipated to run US$2.5 million per unit, with a production goal of US$1 million per unit in quantities of 50 or more.<ref name=signal1/>
==Development== The FORESTER program is being managed by DARPA's Information Innovation Office (I2O), and the hardware is manufactured for DARPA by [[SRC Inc|SRC]] at their Syracuse, NY, headquarters. The initial prototype for the FORESTER was flight tested using a [[UH-60 Blackhawk]] helicopter<ref name=avweek080331/> because the A160 had not yet completed its Phase 1 flight test program. Test flights with the A160 began in August 2008.<ref name=avweek080331/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.darpa.mil/ipto/programs/forester/docs/FORESTER.wmv DARPA CG animation video] showing FORESTER on the [[Boeing A160 Hummingbird]]
[[Category:DARPA|FORESTER]] [[Category:Military radars]]

revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=February 2016}} {{Psychology sidebar|basic}}
'''Differential psychology''' studies the ways in which individuals differ in their behavior and the processes that underlie it. This is distinguished from other aspects of psychology in that although psychology is ostensibly a study of individuals, modern psychologists often study groups, or attempt to discover general psychological processes that apply to all individuals.<ref name="Ergodicity">{{cite journal |author1=Fisher, A.J.| displayauthors=etal| year = 2018 | title = Lack of group-to-individual generalizability is a threat to human subjects research| journal = PNAS | volume = 115 | issue = 27 | pages = 6106–6115| doi=10.1073/pnas.1711978115}}</ref>
For example, in evaluating the effectiveness of a new therapy, the mean performance of the therapy in one [[Treatment and control groups|treatment group]] might be compared to the mean effectiveness of a [[placebo]] (or a well-known therapy) in a second, control group. In this context, differences between individuals in their reaction to the experimental and control manipulations are actually treated as errors rather than as interesting phenomena to study.
This approach is applied because [[psychological research]] depends upon statistical controls that are only defined upon groups of people. Individual difference psychologists usually express their interest in individuals while studying groups by seeking dimensions shared by all individuals but upon which individuals differ. The ergodicity problem impedes correct group-to-individual generalization for most psychological phenomena.<ref name="Ergodicity"/>
== Importance of individual differences == Individual differences are essential whenever we wish to explain how individuals differ in their behavior. In any study, significant variation exists between individuals. [[Reaction time]], preferences, values, and health-linked behaviors are just a few examples. Individual differences in factors such as [[personality]], [[intelligence]], [[memory]], or physical factors such as body size, sex, age, and other factors can be studied and used in understanding this large source of variance. Importantly, individuals can also differ not only in their current state, but in the magnitude or even direction of response to a given [[Stimulus (psychology)|stimulus]]. Such phenomena, often explained in terms of [[Yerkes-Dodson law|inverted-U]] response curves, place differential psychology at an important location in such endeavours as [[personalized medicine]], in which diagnoses are customised for an individual's response profile.
== Areas of study == Individual differences research typically includes [[personality psychology|personality]], [[motivation]], [[intelligence]], ability, [[IQ]], [[Interest (emotion)|interests]], [[Value (personal and cultural)|values]], [[self-concept]], [[self-efficacy]], and [[self-esteem]] (to name just a few). There are few remaining "differential psychology" programs in the United States, although research in this area is very active. Current researchers are found in a variety of applied and experimental programs, including [[clinical psychology]], [[educational psychology]], [[Industrial and organizational psychology]], [[personality psychology]], [[social psychology]], [[behavioral genetics]], and [[developmental psychology]] programs, in the [[neo-Piagetian theories of cognitive development]] in particular.
== See also == * [[Educational psychology]] * [[Intelligence]] * [[Personality psychology]] * [[Behavioral genetics]]
{{clear}}
== References == {{Library resources box|by=no|onlinebooks=no|about=yes|wikititle=differential psychology}} <references />
== Further reading == * [http://www.wilderdom.com/personality/L1-1Introduction.html Introduction to Individual Differences] (Wilderdom) * {{cite book|author1=Maltby, J.|author2=Day, L.|author3=Macaskill, A.|lastauthoramp=y|year=2007|title=Personality, Individual Differences and Intelligence|location=London|publisher=Pearson Education|url=http://www.pearsoned.co.uk/Bookshop/detail.asp?item=100000000090816}} * {{cite journal|author1=Buss, D.M.|author2=Greiling, H.|lastauthoramp=y|year=1999|url=http://labs.la.utexas.edu/buss/files/2015/09/adapt-ID-revisited-1999-jop.pdf|title=Adaptive Individual Differences|journal=Journal of Personality|volume=67|issue=2|pages=209–243|doi=10.1111/1467-6494.00053}} * {{cite journal|author1=Chamorro-Premuzic, T. |author2=Furhnam, A. |lastauthoramp=y |year=2006 |title=Intellectual competence and the intelligent personality: A third way in differential psychology |journal=[[Review of General Psychology]] |volume=10 |issue=3 |pages=251–267 |url=http://www.goldsmiths.ac.uk/psychology/downloads/ChamorroPremuzicFurnham2006RGP.pdf |doi=10.1037/1089-2680.10.3.251 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090319201449/http://www.goldsmiths.ac.uk/psychology/downloads/ChamorroPremuzicFurnham2006RGP.pdf |archivedate=March 19, 2009 }} * {{cite journal|author1=Kanai, R.|author2=Rees, G.|lastauthoramp=y|year=2011|title=The structural basis of inter-individual differences in human behaviour and cognition|journal=[[Nature Reviews Neuroscience]]|volume=12|pages=231–241|url=http://www.nature.com/nrn/journal/v12/n4/abs/nrn3000.html|doi=10.1038/nrn3000}} *{{cite book|author=Tyler, L.E.|year=1965|title=The psychology of human differences|location=New York|publisher=Appleton Century Crofts}} *[http://www.intelltheory.com/ Timeline of researchers and brief biographies]
{{Psychology|state=collapsed}} {{Portal bar|Psychology}}
[[Category:Branches of psychology]] [[Category:Psychology]] [[Category:Behavioural sciences]]
